title: Davidvictorson
author: Davidvictorson
content: Headline 1QuoteBillionaire businessman, Femi Otedola, has been making headlines due to his recent acquisition of 6.3% shares in Transnational Corporation Plc, Transcorp, making him the second largest shareholder of the company. The development has roused the Nigerian financial market as well as caused controversy regarding the relationship between Otedola and his friend, Tony Elumelu as they struggle to control the ownership interest in Transcorp.https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.vanguardngr.com/2023/04/transcorp-share-acquisition-i-admire-otedola-call-him-ote-dollar-elumelu-douses-tensionon/amp/%3ffbclid=IwAR06fxDhXNqOoptQrLlQ_rjXlAePk8qK81TAYwBRlRb-jLjZ3FwPZNnGOlQHeadline 2QuoteNigerian businessman Femi Otedola divested his newly acquired stake in Transnational Corporation of Nigeria (Transcorp) to Chairman Tony Elumelu, sources told PREMIUM TIMES Friday, pulling the plug on the scramble for the top ownership of the group.The billionaire sold his substantial shareholding of 6.3 per cent, a haul of 2.6 billion shares bought in separate transactions, to Mr Elumelu. Earlier, within days of his acquisition of a substantial shareholding, Mr Elumelu had racked up his interest from 2.07 to 25.9 per cent.https://www.premiumtimesng.com/business/business-news/595579-otedola-gives-up-top-ownership-race-in-transcorp-sells-stake-to-elumelu.htmlThis gist shake the whole Nigerian economic landscape. Abeg make person help explain wetin happen between Otedola and Elumelu.I don try to follow the gist but I nor understand am. Dem dey beef? Na control over Transcorp cause the wahala? I sabi say the two of them na padi padi and dem agree to run the organization but wetin really happen wey be Otedola sell him shares? Make una help me out. I go like hear and understand the inside gists too

comments.author: Marykeller
comments.body: Read the full gist as wetin lead to beef between the two billionairesQuoteFemi Otedola Tells His Side of the Story, Accuses Tony Elumelu of Backstabbing and Taking Advantage of his Bankruptcy in 2008...Otedola's Strong claims: Otedola gave Elumelu $20 million in 2005 to buy UBA. In 2008, Otedola went Bankrupt and Elumelu took over his $20m shares in UBA to offset interests in his loans. Read Otedola's words:‚ÄúIn 2005, while Tony was the Managing Director of Standard Trust Bank he approached me to get funds to acquire UBA. I enthusiastically gave him $20million, which was N2billion at that time to buy the necessary shares in UBA for the acquisition. After a short period of time, the share price moved up and I decided it is was a good moment to sell and get out of the bank. However, Tony appealed to me to hold on to the shares as he was convinced that there were future prospects ‚Äì so I kept the shares.‚ÄúI became Chairman of Transcorp Hotel in 2007 with a shareholding of 5% and unknowingly Tony gradually started buying shares quietly.‚ÄúBy the following year in 2008 I went bankrupt in Nigeria. Tony proceeded to take my shares in UBA to service the interest on my loans and he also took over my shares in Africa Finance Corporation, where I was the largest shareholder.‚ÄúShortly after, Albert Okumagba informed me that an American firm wanted to acquire my shares in Transcorp, which I then agreed to sell. However, this supposed American firm turned out to be Tony Elumelu. The revelation of this prompted me to resign as Chairman of the hotel.‚ÄúYears later in 2012 Tony said he wanted to see me so we met in my office where I had previously had a meeting with foreign investors who had not yet departed the premises. Curious to know, he asked what sort of meeting I had had and I disclosed that I wanted to go into the power business, specifically Ughelli Power Plant. Tony quietly went ahead to bid for Ughelli and he outbidded me by offering to buy the plant for $300million.‚ÄúAnd as a some would say: the rest is history.‚ÄúFast forward to the present‚Ä¶‚ÄúI offered to buy Transcorp Plc for N250 billion, but unfortunately, my offer was rejected. My goal was to maximise the company‚Äôs potential as a Nigerian conglomerate with a market cap of at least N2 trillion instead of the current N40 billion, but it seems some shareholders have a different vision.‚ÄúAs a businessman, I believe in healthy competition and market dynamics. Two captains cannot man a ship, and I respect the majority shareholder‚Äôs decision to buy me out. This is the nature of the game.‚ÄúBut let me be clear: my offer was made with the best intentions for Transcorp Plc and its shareholders. I saw an opportunity to unlock the company‚Äôs full potential and create value for everyone involved.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important for investors to understand that free entry and free exit are crucial to healthy markets. The scramble for shares after my acquisition is a testament to the value that Transcorp Plc can offer, and I hope the company continues to thrive under new leadership.‚ÄúMy message to Transcorp Plc and its shareholders is this: I remain committed to the growth and success of Nigerian businesses, and I will always be looking for ways to create value for all stakeholders. Stakeholders are unfortunately always shortchanged by getting stipends while the owners and managers of the business live a jet set lifestyle, which is detrimental to the stakeholders. Thank you for the opportunity to engage in this exciting chapter of Transcorp‚Äôs history.‚ÄùElumelu has yet to officially react to the allegations levelled against him.Source: Premium Times Link: https://www.premiumtimesng.com/business/597539-exclusive-otedola-opens-up-on-relationship-with-elumelu-transcorp-shares.htmlWetin I go fit add to this be sae, as business d so, them no d get permanent friends nor permanent enemies inside am. A friend wey you disclose your big move to today, go fit outsmart you tomorrow. Make you no go disclose your business idea or plans give another peso no matter how close una be.

But shah, they are both billionaire big men, and who am I to argue where two big elephants dey dance. Na there money, and na only them could choose how to spend am oh.

comments.body: I believe Sahara Report published an article yesterday regarding this matter. According to the report, Otedola responded and labeled Tony Elemelu as a betrayer. However, the main concern is why this information was made public. It's not appropriate to air their grievances in public. They should keep their issues private.
